Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Performance through Instability -- An Integrated Theoretical and Experimental Study of the Mechanics of Multiscale Material Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is to understand how microscale instabilities in multiscale material systems affect their macroscopic mechanical response, and how they can be exploited to result in tunable low-frequency acoustic band gaps and order-of-magnitude increases in the overall (visco)elastic properties, which will be demonstrated explicitly for metal-polymer structural materials. The integrated theoretical, computational and experimental strategy promises to result in what is urgently needed to advance opportunities in metamaterials: i) experimentally-confirmed physical understanding of effective properties and stability of multiscale systems, ii) computational models for advanced structural materials, and iii) proof-of-concept experiments leading to a novel class of light-weight functional high stiffness-high damping materials for applications ranging from seismic protection and scientific vibration isolation to acoustic wave guides and filters.

Owing to their superb physical properties, the new materials expected to emerge from the proposed research stand to improve a variety of commercial products in aerospace, automotive, and civil engineering, in the defense, transportation, energy and telecommunication industries, and to result in new technologies. The multidisciplinary approach and the potential for technology transfer will promote scientific collaborations beyond Caltech and with industry. The educational component will make a significant impact both locally ? through sustainably improving K-12 STEM education by a long-term classroom partnership program and by promoting hands-on research experience ? and globally ? through international collaborations and research opportunities, and by providing new research-integrated educational resources to students and educators world-wide. Research and teaching will prepare future scientists and engineers for the key challenges in the emerging interdisciplinary field of engineered material systems and provide opportunities for students of all levels to become involved.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While engineering design has traditionally aimed at avoiding mechanical instabilities, this project has sought new avenues to exploit mechanical instability for the creation of novel materials systems with controlable and exciting mechanical performance. Research included theory, simulations, and experiments and used structural metamaterials (i.e., materials made of small-scale structural members) as the basis for probing the influence of small-scale instabilities on the large-scale material response. A structural instability (such as the buckling of beams or plates) is associated with a multistable energy landscape: multiple stable equilibrium configurations exist and the system is free to (or can be forced to) transition between those. What is commonly found in materials undergoing phase transformations can be replicated at the structural level in metamaterials through controlled buckling or snapping events. This project has investigated the impact of such small-scale instabilities on the macroscale response of metamaterials, particularly focusing on two relatively unexplored areas: dynamics and nonlinearity. We showed that, unlike under static conditions, instability under dynamic conditions can lead to interesting band gaps in the dispersion relations (implying that acoustic waves can be guided and attenuated by a careful control of instability) and that the range of stable effective material properties can be greatly expanded under dynamic conditions (constituents of negative stiffness, classically unstable under static considerations, can be stable and improve the overall mechanical behavior of a composite material under dynamic conditions). We further explored the nonlinear dynamics of multistable metamaterials, which revealed a plethora of new and beneficial phenomena. Starting with simple 1D chain models and advancing to higher dimensions and more complex nonlinear behavior, we showed how multistability in periodic architectures can lead to stable nonlinear transition waves of constant speed due to a balance between energy release upon snapping from one equilibrium to the other and the dissipated energy due to damping in the system. This was verified both theoretically and numerically at different scales, resulting in all-soft architectures of high damping which admit the propagation of constant-speed pulses without the need for electric or other signals (with potential for soft robotics and morphing or reconfigurable structures). We have shown the close relation between such snapping structures and phase transformations in materials - both qualitatively and quantitatively - and have conceived a series of large-scale structural analogs of atomic-scale structural transformation phenomena in materials (from phase transitions to ferroelectric switching). In addition to the discovery of new mechanics and physics, we have also developed new theoretical and computational tools to extract the effective material behavior of architected metamaterials, which includes (i) new homogenization schemes that predict the linear and nonlinear macroscale material response based on unit-cell calculations on the smaller scales, (ii) a new way to assess and visualize directional wave guiding in truss networks (improving upon the classical dispersion curves), and (iii) new meshfree numerical techniques that admit simulating large deformations and distortions without many of the shortcomings of finite element techniques in this scenario. Besides generating scientific impact through the demonstration of new physical phenomena and the development of new widely applicable tools and techniques of intellectual merit, broader impact was achieved through outreach to local high school students (through lab visits, internships, and presentations) and domestic and international undergraduate and graduate students (through visits and research projects) with attention to underrepresented minorities, and the training of graduate students and postdocs who all continued onto successful career trajectories in industry and academia.
